metadata.title: Title: Prediction of the Epidemic Peak of Covid19 in Egypt, 2020

body_text.text: The first case of respiratory disease caused by a novel coronavirus was identified in 2 Wuhan City, Hubei Province, China in In December 2019 and on 13 January 2020 the 3 first case outside of China was reported in Thailand. 1 On 11 th March 2020 the World 4 Health Organization named it coronavirus disease 2019 and considered as 5 pandemic. 2 The first case appeared in Egypt on 14 th February 2020 for a foreigner and 6 fortunately was asymptomatic until 1 st of March 2020 he was the only reported case after 7 that few cases started to appear till 14 th March 2020 to reach 110 cumulatively, and then 8 the number of laboratory confirmed cases increased weekly ( to cope with social distancing and Ramadan habits . . body_text.text: The copyright holder for this preprint this version posted May 5, 2020. . https://doi.org/10. 1101 /2020 Researcher used SEIR Peak prediction models almost similar results obtained; earliest 1 peak could be May 17, 2020 and latest peak could be by July 15, 2020.
body_text.section: (which was not certified by peer review)

body_text.text: The 3 rd scenario was estimating the peak time without lockdown and other strategies 4 based on mobility changes report released by google 11 that stated average 50% reduction 5 in Egypt since the time of lockdown and mitigation strategies. The peak was estimated to 6 occur on 11 th April 2020 but with mitigation strategies and lockdown it was shifted about 7 69 days to reach June 15, 2020 (figure 2). in Ramadan (the Holy month) that will start on April 24, 2020 will affect the timing of 19 peak as a result of Increase in β (transmission rate). We simulated different situations 20 with different rates of effective contact, transmission rate and R 0 consequently; the peak 21 timing changed to reach 20 May, 2020 as earliest one and latest peak could be July 18, 22 2020. These findings was in concordance with the study done by Pearsn et al 12 that 23 . The copyright holder for this preprint this version posted May 5, 2020. . https://doi.org/10. 1101 /2020 reported 10,000 cases could be in 20 May 2020. On the contrast a recent report released 1 by SUTD Data-Driven Innovation Lab 13 that reported the pandemic will end in Egypt 2 on May 20, 2020. Researcher simulated another scenario based on current data to predict 3 the timing of peak without lockdown the peak shifted earlier to be on April 11, 2020; the 4 mitigation strategies helped to delay peak. The current study simulated different The study stated long range peak prediction to emphasis the role of social distancing to 12 flatten the curve in concordance with Anderson et al 16 . 13 The result suggests that the epidemic of COVID-19 in Egypt would not end so quickly. 14 This might be reliable with the WHO's statement on 6 March 2020 that it is a false hope 15 that COVID-19 will disappear in the summer like the flu. 17
body_text.section: (which was not certified by peer review)

body_text.text: Limitations 17 This is too idealistic for modeling COVID-19 as the reproduction number (R0) changes 18 overtime but the multiple simulation may overcome this hypothetically for certain time.

The deterministic models are not accurate and used to give insight about what will 20 happen to population on average. Study didn't estimate the hospitalized number at the 21 surge however the timing of the peak didn't affected by the identified cases form the 22 actual infective population.

24 During COVID-19 pandemic it's hard to predict the real peak timing however the surge 25 timing will depend mainly on the behavior of citizens towards social distancing and 26 hygiene measures. The mitigation strategies and lockdown in Egypt has a positive effect 27 on the delay of the epidemic peak, giving more time to the health sector to encompass the 28 situation. There is an urgent need for Local and worldwide policy to deal with Covid19 29 that will extend to summer time. Egyptian government should monitor the reported cases 30 daily along with the performance of citizens in the coming month to determine the proper 31 . FIGREF1.text: S(t), E(t), I(t) and R(t) represent the susceptible, exposed, infective and removed 15 populations at time t, respectively. β, ɛ and γ represent the infection rate, the onset rate 16 and the removal rate, respectively. 1/ɛ and 1/γ imply the average incubation period and 17 the average infectious period, respectively. The force of infection (rate of infection per 18 unit time is βI and β denoted the rate of transmission from S to I or effective contact 19 between S and I. 520These models based on Euler`s Method: A numerical method for solving differential 21 equations and referred to as a compartment model since it is useful to refer to people 22 moving from one compartment to another.23Parameters used in the models based on previous studies assuming average Incubation 24 period = 5 days and so onset rate ɛ= 0.2 6 , assuming infectious period = 10 day and so 25 removal rate γ=0.1. 7 Egypt population (1x10 8 ) 8 , no one infected at the time (t 0 ) time step 26 is one day and population remain constant so S±E+I+R=1.

FIGREF2.text: used SIR model with different simulation scenarios to predict peak timing, 15 illustrated in figure1. The earliest of peak could be on May 20, 2020 and latest peak could 16 be July 18, 2020, then applied Applying regression method to estimate the best fitted 17 models with the cumulative data released by MOHP till 17th April, 2020; (1): Different models estimating different peaks with SIR model 21 22

FIGREF3.text: (2): Peak estimation with lockdown and other measures in comparison to the 12 situation without them. study, by applying the SIR and SEIR compartmental model along with the daily 16 reported cases of Covid19 till 17 th April in Egypt; we estimated the peak could be in the 17 middle of June. We hypothesized that the social and contact rate per individual changes 18

FIGREF4.text: different values on transmission rate (calculated and estimated) in 6 concordance with Bootsma and Ferguson 14 who stated the most important factor 7 affecting disease pandemic is the transmission rate which depend on crowding as it 8 affects amount of contact per individual. The current study used SIR and SEIR models 9 which are too idealistic for modeling COVID-19 through numerical simulation, but it 10 gives an idea about when the COVID-19 cases can surge to. 15 11
